metadata.title: The Non-Treachery of Dataset. ArtGAN and WikiArt: Making Art with AI… | by Merzmensch | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: “The famous pipe. How people reproached me for it! And yet, could you stuff my pipe? No, it’s just a representation, is it not? So if I had written on my picture “This is a pipe”, I’d have been…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: a Model, trained on 24k Painting Dataset from Kaggle
Ceci n’est pas une pipe: A Deep Convolutional Network for Fine-art Paintings Classification
Improved ArtGAN for Conditional Synthesis of Natural Image and Artwork

all_paragraphs: “The famous pipe. How people reproached me for it! And yet, could you stuff my pipe? No, it’s just a representation, is it not? So if I had written on my picture “This is a pipe”, I’d have been lying!” — wrote René Magritte about his brilliant concept and artwork “The Treachery of Images”.

Magritte explored the dimensions of Reality — and our conventions: the ideal one (a concept of a pipe), the fictional one (painting of a pipe), and the real one (the actual pipe). He also questioned what is real. In his lesser-known visual essay “Let Mots et les Images” (“Words and Images”, a semiological masterpiece) he illustrated the diverse levels of perception, and also his art conception (mixing and replacing terminology, objects, and images on various levels):
In the Digital Age new category emerged and added to these definitions… But how can we call the artworks created by an AI? Is it a Concept? A Fiction? Or already the Reality?
The designer, engineer, AI artist, and thinker samim conflated the discourse very aptly:
Where we humans find an art, AI detects as an object. Objet trouvé?
But what happens when we train AI on Art? What will Android say about electric sheep beyond its dreams?
There were various efforts for letting AI create art (e.g., a Model, trained on 24k Painting Dataset from Kaggle).

AI researcher Chee Seng Chan and his co-researchers asked themselves the same question. They trained CNN on WikiArt Datasets and presented 2016 their paper “Ceci n’est pas une pipe: A Deep Convolutional Network for Fine-art Paintings Classification”. They had a double-sided task:

On one hand, we would like to train an end-to-end deep convolution model to investigate the capability of the deep model in fine-art painting classification problem. On the other hand, we argue that classification of fine-art collections is a more challenging problem in comparison to objects or face recognition. This is because some of the artworks are non-representational nor figurative, and might requires imagination to recognize them (source / ICIP-16).
So does AI has the imagination to recognize art, a non-representational production of the human brain, heart, and hand? And can AI be inspired and generate art?

So they released ArtGAN to explore the possibilities of AI in its relation to ART. 2017 new study and Improved ArtGAN was published: Improved ArtGAN for Conditional Synthesis of Natural Image and Artwork.
Based on ArtGAN, using a conditional WikiArt model, and enabled by StyleGAN2 and TensorFlow, Peter Baylies released a new Model: (GitHub / conditional model).
He started his experiment last year — with this twitter thread:
The beauty of this project also begins with collaboration: so many efforts by various researchers are combined in this model. And it convinces with its power.
Let’s explore WikiArt (thank Doron Adler for providing and fine-tuning a Colab Notebook of WikiArt).
In fact, the model is trained on many artists, but for genre classification, only some of them are chosen:

The Wikiart paintings dataset has a collection of more than 80,000 fine-art paintings from more than 1,000 artists, ranging from fifteen century to modern times. This dataset contains 27 different styles and 45 different genres. […] all paintings are used for style classification. Meanwhile, only 10 genres with more than 1,500 paintings are chosen for genre classification, with a total of around 65,000 samples. (CS Chan)
Indeed, style classification is a complex story, the object of discussions between art scholars.

All these questions cannot be answered even by human beings (based on conventions, stereotypes, and even self-manifestations of artists). AI is perplexed as well — the most it can do, is distinguishing between artist styles, depicted objects, and art movement features.
You can choose between these three-categories-sets and let AI recreate the task.
So let’s begin with Rembrandt — pretty 0bvious choice. Sure, what we get, is not your Next Rembrandt, but the results resemble the style of the Maestro:
Just look a the brushstrokes in AI-generated image. And compare with Rembrandts’ master's hand:
This is not just a StyleTransfer. This is something more. Recapitulation of Rembrandts’ Œuvre.
If we pick up UTAGAWA Kuniyoshi…
Even if the style is far from original, the composition, the feeling, the mood — all the human shapes, lazy day, 物の哀れ. Already Impressionist touch.
Exactly: ArtGAN cannot reconstruct famous paintings (in this case because it’s trained on the huge dataset from various art epochs). It also cannot create artworks on demand.
But it produces auratic images speaking for themselves.
We also can ask a blasphemous question: what if? Artists creating in different styles? Da Vinci as Impressionist? Van Gogh in Renaissance?
Playing around with the categories you achieve surprisingly interesting results. Here are just some of them.
The model of Peter Baylies provides even more, including Projector, analog to StyleGAN2.
Yes, it is! At the same moment, as Neural Networks deliver an image, it becomes part of our reality.

You decide. In my opinion, this is the art in the meaning of Dadaists. It’s a disruptive force which lets us re-consider the human factor in the concept of art. Like in all pivotal moments of the art history: be it Renaissance or Historian Avant-garde.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Futurist. AI-driven Dadaist. Living in Germany, loving Japan, AI, mysteries, books, and stuff.
